title: "TransCal" 50s script
content:
I have searched every where I know for this one.   
   
Please help if you can.   
   
Thank you. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/18555.jpg)
author: amiart

comments.content: Yves thats why I sent him here. He was getting nowhere at the MyFont Idenifcation forum. Dan
Yves, its not just you, there are some really talented people who visit this site. Chill out and have another ice tea. Dan
Yves, Eduardo Omine and Mike Yanega are no slouches when it comes to idenifing type. You have the troops at this site. Dan

Jared, I think you may have gotten as close as we can get to this one. I agree Trafton has many very similar features, but my guess is that it may have been a style model for this Trans Cal logo artwork. In other words, I think the reason we have had such a hard time with this is that it is not a font at all. (I know these are sometimes 'famous last words', but I just don't think this looks like any font I've seen except House Industries ["Fabulous"](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/Script07Pg5.html) (at the bottom of the page), which is also rather close to this. Trafton image follows (also from the Script Guide, and note that the letters do not connect -- something it's hard to tell from sample books): ![Trafton Sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/18625.gif)
Another quick thought.. Could the T and the C be a different font from the others .. or possibly hand drawn? and if so what font is the other part?

This post keeps bumping itself up toward the top of the list, despite having no new posts since Yves' sensible conclusion on the 19th.   
   
Thought I'd see if a new post would cure what ails it.

I have to resurrect this again.. I have not found this I still suspect it to be a font.. and as of yet have not found it I could redraw however I would like the origional font for text additions etc..

Wow, now <cite>this</cite> is a long hunt...  
Maybe a record for an "active" type-ID?

hhp

_\> He was getting nowhere at the MyFont Identification   
forum._      
   
I don't think I can take the pressure anymore... ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

_\> Yves, its not just you_   
Thank you for reminding me. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/lol.gif) I _DO_ get a little   
self-centered since I got credited co-moderator.   
   
_\> there are some really talented people who visit   
this site._      
Are you inferring something Dan? ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/biggrin.gif)

All I can come up with are near misses.   
   
 [Futura Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/futura-script/ef/testdrive.html?s=TransCal&p=48)   
   
Novelty Script by Solotype   
   
Flair (in FontShop's Font Book, under "Script" pg 41) - Can't find it on their site   
   
 [Gillies Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdisplay&displayfontid=EF.1076.0.0&packagefontid=0&view=package&searchID=0&searchby=keyword&searchletter=A&searchstr=gillies%20gothic&totalrecords=24&startrow=1&records=20&currpage=1) (FontShop)   
   
Magneto (FontShop) - in the same vein, somewhat

wait! I think I found it, although in a lighter weight, in my Reardon & Krebs Typographers (1955, $5 at a garage sale) - I'm pretty confident this is it, but lighter.   
   
Trafton Script [bold?] (by Bauer?) (Mentions: [1](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.garloo.com/bauer.htm), [2](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.headheritage.co.uk/unsung/reviews/index.php?review_id=372), [3](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/ListPages/ScriptListST.html), [4](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.ironivy.com/sets/springhassprung/springsprung.html), [5](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/neufville.com/FontData/FONTS_AZ.htm), [6](http://web.archive.org/web/20141113020349/http:/www.delphipress.com/Edu_Pg/Prof_Aspirations/Prof_Asp_GIF_JPEG/DY_Lettering_1.htm))

Frankly, to me this looks like some 50s air company   
custom drawn logo, really. I haven't got high hopes   
of someone finding an exact match. It all looks pretty   
homogenous, so I don't think there's subsituted   
characters or anything like that.
